answers.answer: In most patients, stenting and, more importantly, aggressive medical therapy holds or attenuates progression of coronary artery disease.  The same isn't true for patients with diabetes.  They tend to progress.  The fact that you are having more symptoms would make me pursue further investigation.  One thing I should mention, is that patients with diabetes tend to do better with bypass surgery, especially if the LAD is involved.  Mention that to your doctors.

question: I AM 47 YRS OLD WITH SOME HEART PROBLEMS I HAD A HEART ATTACK 3YRS AGO AND HAVE HAD 5 STENTS PUT IN AND HAVE SINCE HAD 2 MORE PUT IN ALL MOSYLY IN THE LAD 1 IN THE MAIN CIRCUMFLEX DURING THE PROCEDURE MY CARDIOLIGIST STATED MY RIGHT RCA HAD A 40% BLOCKAGE 3 YRS AGO BEING THAT ALL THE WORK SINCE HASBEEN ON THE LEFT SIDE COULD THAT 40% BECOME MORE BLOCKED CAUSING NOW MY RESTING HEART RATE TO BE 95 TO 110 ALL THE TIME SHOULD I BE CONCERENED ALSO I STILL GET CHEST PAIN WHEN EXCERTING MYSELF AND ALOT OF TIMES JUST RESTING. ALSO SOMETIMES I FEEL A LITTLE LIGHTHEADED. I CHECKED MY BLOOD PRESSURE WHEN I NOTICED MY RESTING HEART RATE AT 105 AND IT WAS 165/105 I TAKE ALL MY MEDCINES TO KEEP THIS UNDER CONTROL BUT IT DOESNT SEEM TO HELP I ALSO HAVE TYPE 2 DIB. ANY THOUGHTS WOULD BE GREATLY APPREC
title: fast  resting heart rate???
